messages: c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (19:39): wonders if anyone knows if FTP labels resources with a MIME type? (i.e., using something equiv. to HTTP's content-type)?
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:40): All you need is a web service that translates any page into HTML5, and now all the pretty web pages on the web can be HTML5
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:40): c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774: I'm almost entirely certain that it doesn't
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:40): It's up to the client to even decide between ASCII and binary before downloading a file - the server just has a stream of bytes

c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (19:42): Will I get laughed at if I use the following definition in the widget spec?: In this specification, the network is any data transfer protocol that labels resources with a MIME type. For example, HTTP.
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:45): (HTTP 0.9 didn't have MIME types)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:45): HTTP/0.9 didn't have anything.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (19:45): just GET /foobar

3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (19:46): c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774: If you have e.g. an MHTML file where you bundle a load of resources together with MIME types, would you count that as a "network"?

c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (19:47): reads "each of us personally would like to see the XHTML2 and HTML groups brought together or at least the overlaps removed." I thought the role of the chair was to "chair", not to bring in their own agenda.... anyway.
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (19:48): Maybe "network" is not the right word there.

c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (19:50): I'm trying to make a distinction between things labelled with a MIME type and things not labelled. I currently have "network" and "Local storage or other media". Where "Local storage or other media  is defined as any means of data acquisition that does not label resources with a MIME type. For example, from a hard disk or memory card, or over the air from BlueTooth or infrared."
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (19:56): c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774: ftp works only with two modes to the best of my knowledge: text or binary for transfert
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (19:58): Maybe it is one of the issues of the Web. Files have not been (are still not) created on the Web for a while.
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (20:05): I'll run with what I have so far and see what happens at LC :)
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (20:06): hmm interesting, there is a mention of FTP in RFC 2046 - http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2046.txt
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (20:06): 5.2.3.2.  The 'ftp' and 'tftp' Access-Types
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (20:07): "The valid values for access-type "FTP" are
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (20:07): "ASCII", "EBCDIC", "IMAGE", and "LOCALn" where "n" is a
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (20:07): decimal integer, typically 8."
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:31): c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774: Can you call them "resources labelled with a MIME type" and "resources not labelled with a MIME type"?
3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2 (20:32): c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774: Sounds like the easiest way to make that distinction :-)
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (20:32): 3f2e2531201cfbf853f16f668132eaf2: true. I'll rewrite the section now.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (20:33): f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb: man, that really has to predate the concept of URIs :-)

f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (20:40): I guess there are at least two ways: a server/client dialog where the server says "Yo man, I'm sending you this stream with this format/encoding" Or the protocol says "all your communications buddies must be done on 8bits, if you want more information about the content, inspect the first lines of the content"
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (20:46): Apart from HTTP, what are some other protocols that label resources with MIME types?
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (20:49): I guess protocols modeled after HTTP, such as SIP?
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (20:49): takes a look
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (20:50): looks like a job for a script that goes through all RFCs and looks for references to the MIME RFCs
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (20:52): 60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28: I'm just trying to add some examples to the widget spec of protocols that use/don't use MIME.
c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774 (20:52): nothing too serious
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (20:59): a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d: congratulations on your appointment
f47636673b14c54021a69dc06f6a19fb (20:59): something like http://www.ask.com/web?q=%22RFC%202045%22%20%2Bsite%3Awww.ietf.org/rfc
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (20:59): Title: "RFC 2045" +site:www.ietf.org/rfc - Ask.com Search (at www.ask.com)

a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (21:38): btw, I am planning to come to Google on the 28th and 29th (for ECMAScript), and could come a day or so early -- if that made any sense.

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:05): "Hi, I'm Sam Ruby, I'm the new divine ruler of the group."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (22:05): i think e-mail would be more effective at reaching the community than a telecon, personally
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (22:05): There probably aren't enough people on the telecon for it to be much use
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (22:06): Email will be necessary as well, of course.
60659cfda992013e610f285c46692d28 (22:06): But my assumption was that the new chair would attend the weekly telco, so the question really was: will there be one this week?
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:07): I'm not co-chair until next month.
a480104b0e570389c6f4284a88c7cd9d (22:08): i.e., ask the current chairs. :-)
